advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> LUCAS LOGIC BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  U.S. AD #2 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Despite the M20 was neither software nor hardware compatible with any other computer, Olivetti had to prove that it had more computing power at a smaller pice than any competitor. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET - INSIDE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QUASAR AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 8 KB quasar system with the 4 color plotter/printer interface.<br><br> The small picture shows a complete system with memory expansion, modem and video interfaces.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TEI BROCHURE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUSSIAN ADVERT - PAGE 1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Taras Ponomarev for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert said : <br><br> <font color="#666666">The 8813 was built with you, the professional, in mind...<br><br> Using the 8813, one person can process what would normally require many secretaries, several bookkeepers and a great deal of time...<br><br> The 8813 slashes the professional's overhead. It's a powerful time and money-saving ally. Prices for complete system including printer start at less than $8,000.</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STUPID PICTURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The same women has changed its shirt... But hey, what's the message behind this pictures ? Would it be that it's sexy to work on an Alpha Plus, or that women prefer men owning an Alpha Plus ?!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Efficient companies choose professional partners"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The Personal Computer MZ-811 is a class of itself. Its infinite applications mark it." <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>NorthStar brochure, Page 1.<br> The brochure says:<br><br> <b>HARDWARE</b><br> The HORIZON computer incorporates a high speed 4 MHz Z80A microprocessor with 64Kb of Dynamic RAM including parity and two 5 1/4 inch floppy disk drives in an attractive desk top chassis. The chassis also provides a 12-slot S-100 mother board which contains a Real-Time Interrupt, two RS-232C serial ports, one 8-bit parallel port and power regulation circuitry for the integrated floppy disk drives. Either a 115 or 230 volt power supply with sufficient power for all 12 slots and the disk drives is also included. The use of high speed (200 nsec) Dynamic RAM and "fast stepping" floppy disk drives, along with the 4 MHz CPU, delivers the highest average performance of all comparable microcomputers as measured by independent benchmark studies! <br><br> <b>SOFTWARE</b><br> The power and versatility of the HORIZON computer is further enhanced by a wide range of system and application software. For business use, the comprehensive North Star Application Software Packages offer Word Processing, Accounting and Financial Reporting in either single user or multi-user versions. For the scientific, engineering, or education oriented user, North Star's powerful DOS operating system with its efficient BASIC or Pascal languages are available. The industry standard CP/M operating system is also compatible with applications packages in MicroSoft BASIC, FORTRAN, and COBOL.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gordon Dyer</b> from England</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advertisement for the HX-10D. If you can read japanese maybe you could tell us what's the difference with a HX-10...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICT. #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://mayura.jp/blog" target="_blank">Mayura Labo</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Karl-Heinz - http://www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TANDY 1988 CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.switchtech.us/Tandy1000.html" target="_blank">SWITCHTECH'S Tandy 1000SX page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (NOV. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the only SILEX advert known so far... <br><br> It says : "Silex, a stone in our competitors garden." <br><br> Silex means flint in french, a stone mainly used in prehistoric times as tools and weapons. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (MAY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>A selection for the Initiator... at Sinclair price</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SILEX DOCUMENTATION</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
The Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) was released in Japan in 1983 under the name Famicom. This was short for Family Computer. Hundreds of games were produced for the system and it sold very well.
It had one of the most unique accessories too; R.O.B (Robotic Operating Buddy). It was controlled by flashes from the screen generated by the game itself. It couldn't do much except move around some discs from one platform to another. It was popular because it was something different.
The NES was home to some of the biggest franchises in video game history and there are still games being made based on characters first seen on the NES. Characters like Mario (who technically was first seen in the Arcades in Donkey-Kong game, though he was called then only "jumpman"), Samus (Metroid), and Link.
Other companies like Sega (Master System) and Atari (Atari 7800) tried to get a piece of the pie with their own systems but neither of them were able to come anywhere near the sales figures of the Nintendo. There is no doubt that the NES was the most popular 8-bit gaming system.
In the early '90s Nintendo redesigned the NES. It was top-loading design and the controllers looked alot like SNES controller except with only 2 buttons. The Famicom (japanese version of the NES) had the longest production life of any console ever to this day from 1983 to 2004 in Japan. It shifted 60 million units in its life time!
A bunch of accessories were available for the NES & Famicom, including : lightgun, ROB the robot, disk drives, BASIC keyboard, dancing mat, power glove, additional controllers and much more...

emulator.description: Jnes is a NES emulator for win32 platforms that uses DirectX for it's hardware interface. It's emulation capabilities include graphics, sound, input devices, and emulating quite a few memory mapping boards found in most USA games and a few popular japanese ones.
emulator.name: JNES

emulator.description: Maybe the best emulator for Windows
emulator.name: NNNesterJ

emulator.description: Zophar's Domain has an excellent selection of NES emulators. Prepare to see a lot of them!
emulator.name: Zophar's Domain

emulator.description: FCE Ultra is a portable NES/Famicom emulator for DOS, Linux and Windows
emulator.name: FCE Ultra

emulator.description: Excellent emulator for Windows, DOS, Linux & MacOS
emulator.name: RockNES

computer.graphics: 256 x 24064 sprites on screen, but only 8 per scanline / sprite size : 8x8 or 8x16 pixels
computer.name: NES
computer.peripherals: power glove, lightgun, Basic keyboard (Famicom), ROB the robot, disk drive (Famicom), dancing carpet, additional controllers...
computer.ports: 2 Controller Ports, Composite Video Out, Mono Audio Out, RF Out, Expansion Port

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> DEMONSTRATION UNIT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a demonstration unit used in some stores selling the NES. It operates like a jukebox. Up to twelve cartridges can be inserted into the unit. Then, the game is selected by a "Game Select" button. At the rear of the system, a knob is used to select accorded playing time: 30 seconds, 3 minutes, 6 minutes or ... 120 minutes!</blockquote>

computer.sound: 4 Channel Mono - 2 Square Waves, 1 Triangle Wave, 1 White Noise
